characters: NOTICE FROM THE OFFICE OF THE FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGA
PUBLISHED, REPRODUCED, SOLD OR DISTRIBUTED BY ANY MEANS,
INC. DISPOSAL OF THIS SCRIPT COPY DOES NOT ALTER ANY OF T
MEDIUM, INCLUDING ANY WEB SITE, WITHOUT THE PRIOR WRITTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 Mostly darkness in the small apartment, a few table lamps illuminating a comfortable, crowded well worn space. On o shelf, souvenirs from a past life: a framed NY Times Best Seller list from 1980 with Kilgallen by Lee Israel highlighted in the number 15 spot. Five or six copies of book, and a similar number of Miss Tallulah Bankhead (als Lee) and many more of Estee Lauder by Lee Israel line a shelf. It’s a bit of a trophy case. Across the room, a well worn cat tree sits in the corner, piles of New Yorkers, and LEE ISREAL, around 50 and not trying very hard, is asleep in her clothes on the couch. Blossom Dearie record spins on the record player, a cat snoozes in her lap. Both snore. An alarm beeps on Lee’s c digital watch. Finally, she rouses. She looks down at her watch which reads 10pm, and stops the alarm. She moves to the kitchen, responding slightly to the musi We imagine she may be getting ready for bed. She puts her plate in the sink, and returns. She downs her water from table and puts the glass into her purse. She takes a bott of scotch and also puts it into her purse. She turns off light, but then the front door opens, hall-light pouring and we see Lee exit. The door slams shut. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nondescript cubicles and the nondescript people who are working in them. It is the graveyard shift and the YOUNG EMPLOYEES are proofreading and black-lining law documents The large room is eerily silent save for the scratching o pencils on paper and the sound of ICE CLINKING in a glass Lee is working as well, drinking a scotch on the rocks. S swirls it around absentmindedly as she works without enthusiasm. TWO YOUNG WOMEN pass by her cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Fucking kill me if I’m doing this at her age. Lee hears, and waits til she can’t see them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll kill you now if you ask nicely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 2. 2 Embarrassed giggles. Swirling her glass of scotch, Lee wo Someone shouts from another cubicle, head barely visible

dialogues.speaker: CUBICLE WORKER
dialogues.text: You know we’re not allowed to eat or drink in here!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CUBICLE WORKER
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Yeah. Lee ignores them. The first cubical worker tries to peer to Lee. Hello? Fascist. Alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: A THIRD WORKER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Some laughter. Lee goes back to her work, tries to concentrate. She can’t.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) Why do you give a crap?

dialogues.speaker: CUBICLE WORKER
dialogues.text: Because the sound of the ice is driving me insane.

dialogues.speaker: MANY VOICES
dialogues.text: Me too! It’s making me crazy!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck off. She drinks, making as much ice noise as possible.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I believe I said fuck off. A tall MAN, 30, appears at her cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: I’m your boss. Pack up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 3. 2

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m almost through with this document. Now.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: He takes the document and other papers from her desk and gestures for her to get up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Please, I need this job. He ignores her, watching as she puts her things into her canvas bag (including her glass and bottle of scotch). He walks behind her, ushering her out. The young people in the cubicles watch with amusement as goes. Breaking into loose applause. 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight from the job, Lee puts her groceries up on the counter - cereal, peanut butter, a can of cat food. On th small black and white TV a program with garishly wealthy characters is playing. The CASHIER, 60s Asian woman, is skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: (she knows her) How much have you got?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (fishing in her pocket) Enough.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Show me first. Lee counts out her disappointing amount of cash.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Okay, just this. She separates the cereal and cat food and pays for them.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Put this other stuff back! Lee walks out. 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 4. INT. LEE’S UPPER WEST SIDE APARTMENT - MORNING 4 Lee opens the cat food and places it in front of her cat JERSEY, who’s not interested.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Since when did you become picky. She puts the cereal on the counter and walks through her cluttered apartment. Peeling paint, way too much stuff an years of stacked up New Yorker magazines. The small one bedroom apartment hasn’t been updated in at least 20 year paint is chipping, furniture is worn and scratched by multiple cats, even the light bulbs need dusting. But you tell it was once a well-loved little box of a home. The dining table is covered with papers and coffee cups a empty wine bottles, leaving little room for the manual typewriter and old computer. 5 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 5 A few dead flies lie on her pillow. Disgusted, she brushe them off and curls up to sleep in her clothes. 6 INT. LEE’S BATHROOM - EARLY EVENING 6 Broken shower tiles, an old moldy curtain. In the medicin cabinet mirror, Lee smooths down her hair and applies lipstick. She notices the litter box in the corner is in unused, pristine condition. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 Lee approaches the 1 train entrance at 86th street and descends the stairs. 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 Shivering from the cold, she treks down the New York stre 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Lee has entered a noisy, stylish party. Forty or so festi members of the New York literary world cheerfully enjoy cocktails and conversation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 5. 10 She notices a COAT GUY taking jackets, but she walks past in search of the bar. Her host MARJORIE, 70 years old and sophisticated, sees h

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Well, this is a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You invited me, did you not?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: You didn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (ignoring that) A coat check? At my party we threw coats on a bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Nice to see you too, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) You never call me back. I’ve got some new ideas.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: This is why you’re here?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You don’t know what I’ve been doing just to get by.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Well, you’re here now. Try to enjoy yourself, Lee. Marjorie excuses herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar as Lee gratefully finds it. She gets her drink and turns, walking through the crowd. overhears a conversation between TOM CLANCY, 40 famous writer, and a crowd of eager followers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 6. 10

dialogues.speaker: TOM CLANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t subscribe to the notion of writers block.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWER
dialogues.text: You never experience it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM CLANCY
dialogues.text: Writers block is a term invented by the writing community to justify their laziness. The crowd laughs. TOM CLANCY (CONT’D) My success is nothing more than that I have the dedication and stamina to sit and get the work done. It’s simple.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWER
dialogues.text: Having Ronald Reagan talking about you doesn’t hurt. Well sure.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CLANCY
dialogues.text: Lee passes the conversation, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (walking by) Jackass.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWER
dialogues.text: Who’s that? Tom Clancy shrugs, and Lee wanders, not knowing anybody. People hustle by her, having a good time. SEVERAL YOUNG GUESTS are huddled together and Lee eavesdr

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You have to read them. As an American.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: Well, sure. Lee looks around, landing on SEVERAL OLDER PEOPLE sitting couches, not talking to anybody. They line the perimeter of the room, sipping their drinks They’re old wallflowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 Lee walks down the hall that’s decorated with framed photographs, book jackets, signed letters - it’s Marjorie professional Memory Lane. She glances up to assess TWO FRAMED BOOK JACKETS. One is KILLGALLEN, by Lee Israel and the other is MISS TALLULAH BANKHEAD also by Lee. Unhappy with their placement, she quickly swaps them out a couple of frames that are closer to her eye line. 12 INT. MARJORIE’S POWDER ROOM - EVENING 12 Lee is snooping in the cabinet and finds a drawer filled almost finished toilet paper rolls. A dozen of them at le Weird. She grabs the fullest one and drops it into her large bag She takes the bar of guest soap as well. 13 INT. MARJORIE’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 13 She snakes her way through the party and makes it to the front door just as Marjorie stops her.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: That was quick. Did you get properly fed?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: This week. Will you take my call?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (condescendingly) Sure. We’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I have fascinating projects! I’m working on a lot of ideas - I just need my agent to call me back.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (laughing to herself) Well, nobody needs a new biography on Fanny Brice, Lee. We may disagree on what is considered fascinating. She starts to walk away. MARJORIE (CONT’D) Good night Lee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 8. 13

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (stopping her) Why do you have mostly used toilet paper rolls in the drawer of your bathroom? What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I just can’t figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: You went through my bathroom cabinets?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just tell me. I’m curious.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: So that guests can have a full roll.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s batshit, Marjorie.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (to herself) You would know... At the coat check Lee points to a very sophisticated, lon wool coat.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I lost the ticket, but that’s the one. The coat check guy doesn’t flinch, but hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: COAT CHECK GUY
dialogues.text: Have a good night, ma’am. Lee takes the beautiful coat with a smirk. 14 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER THAT NIGHT 14 Lee sits on her couch, drinking scotch, with her new coat slung over the couch. On the TV Lillian Hellman’s black a white film THE LITTLE FOXES plays. It’s a scene Lee knows heart, but that doesn’t stop her from enjoying every fram (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 9. 14 Bette Davis is snuffing candles whilst quibbling with her brothers Charles Dingle and Carl Benton Reid. Lee loves t

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (along with the TV) There are lots of things to consider. After all, they are first cousins. (then answering herself) Well that isn’t unusual. Our grandmother and grandfather were first cousins. (back again) Yes and look at us! She removes some appetizers from her purse, shoves one in her mouth and offers one to the cat. LEE (CONT’D) Jersey, here girl! The cat wanders over but doesn’t eat them. Lee is concern 15 INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 15 Lee is at the counter, holding a cat carrier and talking the assistant RACHEL.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You still have a balance, Ms. Israel.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: But there’s something wrong with her. She’s very old.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. The doctor told me to get at least half the balance before we do any tests.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Don’t you take a Hippocratic oath or something? Don’t you have to do something?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You owe us eighty two dollars. Lee pulls some bills out of her back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Look, I’ve got - fourteen dollars. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Lee walks out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. 9A. 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Lee enters, wearing her stolen coat, carrying two heavy b of books. 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 GLEN, a 30 year old nerd and the used book buyer, glances briefly at Lee’s pile of old books on the counter. There CUSTOMERS waiting behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Just these. That’s it? here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I schlepped them all the way

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: (dismissive) I’ll give you two dollars. I don’t want the others. He goes to the cash register to pay her.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Come on, man. I don’t need much. I just don’t want to carry them around. (beat) I’ve got a sick cat and I need the money. Please.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: (rude) I told you I don’t want the others. There’s people waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be so disrespectful. You’ve actually carried my books here. Glen turns to her, amused.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (irritated) I’m Lee Israel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 11. 17

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, Ms. Israel. I do recognize you now. In fact, your latest work is right over there! He points to a table of books with a sign “75 percent off Displayed is several copies of Estee Lauder: Behind the Magic.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You rude little ape. What have you ever written? She turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Hey, get your garbage off my counter! He pushes her books away from him and some fall onto the floor. She scoops them up protectively. 18 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - ENTRYWAY - DAY 18 Lee enters her building, and upon seeing Andrei, 50s Romanian, tries to turn around and go right back out, but calls out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi, Andrei.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: I knock on your door but you never answer. We’re going on three months.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, I know. I’m really sorry about that. I’m working on it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: I don’t want to have to call the management.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Can you cut me a little slack? It’s been a rough patch. I just lost my job. I think it was ageism.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: Can’t you write another book? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 12. 18

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Last one was a bit of a calamity.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: I like you, you’ve been here longer than I have, and you’ve always been kind to my mother. Just get it to me soon.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I will. Absolutely. Thank you. Andrei start to walk away. LEE (CONT’D) But hey, in the meantime, do you think you could get an exterminator in my apartment? I’ve got an untenable fly situation. 19 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 19 Lee drinks coffee and reads the newspaper. She glances briefly at a framed letter on her wall. Reluctantly, she to it, takes it from the wall, examining it. It’s a frame letter from Kathryn Hepburn. Lee sighs. She knows what sh has to do, but she doesn’t like it. She takes the letter off the wall. 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Lee walks down the street and enters a beautiful shop wit First Edition Books and Framed Prints in the window. 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Inside the dark and cozy store, Lee stands before ANNA, 4 as she reads the Katherine Hepburn letter.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (reading) Lee, Today was to have been the Esquire shoot with Spence. Difficult days, these. Thank you for your sympathy and understanding. Ever Yours, Kate. P.S. Forgive the splotches. All tears lately. (then) Such a lovely apology. (beat) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 13. 21

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is very special. Why would you part with it?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) Clutter, you know. I’m not a very sentimental gal.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (appreciatively) Handwritten even. You’re the Lee Israel?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. Is there another?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’ve read your biographies! Have you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You’re a wonderful writer.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Can you remind my publisher?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Working on anything new?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Besides my tan? Anna smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: So, how did this letter come about?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I wrote for some magazines a while ago it was going to be Spencer Tracy - but then he died.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, her letters usually have the intimacy of a phone book, but this one is really nice. (beat) How does one seventy five sound?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sounds terrific. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 14. 21

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If you ever are feeling sentimental, you can come visit it! 22 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 22 She takes out a can of cat food and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I got you the good stuff, you old snob! She puts it in a bowl on the floor, but the cat doesn’t m LEE (CONT’D) It’s the fancy feast. 23 EXT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 23 Jack enters. 24 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 24 Lee sits drinking, headphones on. Someone takes the seat near her but she doesn’t look up. about 50, queer and charming. He’s JACK HOCK. He gets the attention of CRAIG, the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, darling. Can I have a beer?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hi Jack, handsome, I don’t know, can you? Jack quickly pulls out a twenty and puts it on the bar. C goes to get the beer. Jack recognizes Lee.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lee Israel!? Lee turns and then recoils, never liking to have to talk anyone. She struggles to pull out a name, taking off her headphones reluctantly. JACK (CONT’D) It’s Jack Hock! And the last time I saw you we were both pleasantly pissed at a horrible book party. Am I right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 15. 24

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s flooding back to me. You were friends with Julia JACK Steinberg. She’s not an agent anymore. She died.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She did? So young.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Or maybe she didn’t die. Maybe she just moved to the suburbs - I always confuse those two. No, that’s right. She got married and had twins.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Better to have died.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Indeed. (excited) I just came from having my teeth bleached. How do they look? He smiles wide. His teeth are almost too white.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Teeth are a dead give-a-way. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (beat) Let me buy you a drink. Even though you’re the posh writer. He signals to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. I’m trying to remember that party you mentioned. Something keeps flashing in my mind. Something that happened but I can’t put my finger on it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bad shrimp? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 16. 24

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Jack Hock, you said?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That’s me. The renegade, the rebel. Jack Hock. Big cock. He flashes his smile. Lee thinks.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It will come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll try not to be offended. We’ve been shit faced drunk together more than once, but...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: My memory is shot. Don’t take it personally. Craig drops a drink for Lee.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How has life been treating you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I can actually boast that I’ve been banned from Crosby Street Booksellers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I did nothing. People are idiots.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (beat) I’m banned from Duane Reade. (beat) All of them. She glares at him. JACK (CONT’D) I have a little shoplifting problem. Lee moves her bag to other side of her stool. JACK (CONT’D) All in the past. But for some reason I have a very memorable mug. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 17. 24 JACK (CONT’D) Now I have to take a bus just to buy shampoo or aspirin or something. (beat) I’m joking. Duane Reade’s not the only rodeo in town.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (dawning on her) You pissed in the closet!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I did what?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I remember now. Nobody could stop talking about the handsome English gentlemanJACK Why thank youLEE Who was so shit-faced he mistook the coat closet for the can. You ruined thousands of dollars worth of furs. Jack is caught, unsure how this will go over. Well, I-

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But Lee loves this story.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Those old ninnies didn’t know what had hit them! Their disgusting furs, all covered with piss. Dogs were following them home. I laughed about that for weeks. Jack starts laughing along with Lee.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well I’m glad somebody found it amusing. (then) A few folks stopped talking to me after that night. Fuck ‘em. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 18. 24 They cheers.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So, do you work, Jack Hock?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This and that. Mostly that. (beat) I happen to have some very nice coke, if you’re interested. She looks at him, appalled. JACK (CONT’D) Jesus, it’s not like I have it all the time. A boy’s gotta do what a boy’s gotta do. (beat) Anyways, who are you to judge? It’s four in the afternoon and you’re drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m hardly drunk. And it’s not “anyways,” it’s just “anyway.”

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well keep drinking then. The day is young. 25 EXT. JULIUS’ BAR - NIGHT They come out and walk. 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Lee and Jack ride the subway.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You get out the next stop?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (nodding) 79th. You?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll get out there. That works. A beat. JACK (CONT’D) I think I saw you in Zabar’s once. You were shouting at someone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Terrible customer service. Been going there for years.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They have really good bread. They both nod comfortably.

dialogues.speaker: A27
dialogues.text: EXT. GLEN’S APARTMENT - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: A27
dialogues.text: A MAN (Glen) comes out of an apartment building with an adorable puppy and attaches it to a leash.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Coco. You’re such a good girl. Lee stares at him and taps Jack.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s the guy - the guy from Crosby Street Booksellers! No!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They watch as he affectionately kisses his dog.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Who knew he was human.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You got a paper and pen? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Why? Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 19A.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lee reaches into her bag and gives him what he needs. He into the vestibule of the guy’s building and looks to be copying names off the buzzer list. 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 They approach Lee’s building.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: This is me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nice place?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It used to be nicer. (beat) And you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 20. 27

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (vague) Oh - a couple blocks up. She reaches out to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good-bye Jack. This was not unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll see you tomorrow? You shall.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She goes into the building. 28 INT. LEE’S LOBBY - CONTINUOUS 28 She goes inside and after a moment, turns to see him thro the glass door, standing there, looking kind of lost. Aft moment, he walks off. 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Lee, dressed neatly, smooths down her hair and knocks on door. LISA, 20s, answers. She seems put off by Lee’s appearance let’s her in. Lisa leads Lee inside.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: The employment agency said this was an executive assistant position.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Your name’s Lee, right?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Ms. Israel, if you don’t mind. MS. WHITMAN, a wealthy, intimidating woman in her 30s eme from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: We do first names here. This is Lisa. I’m Ms. Whitman. They shake. 31 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 31 In the enormous living room, Lee is holding a beige color bra.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Go to Bendels on Fifth. There’s two kinds, but both are under wire, 34B. One has lace on the sides and the other is plain. Get them in Apricot. It’s new. If you can’t find them ask Celeste, she’ll help you. Buy four each. Bring that one with you just to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You know Town shop is just across 86th?

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter. And don’t take a cab. Take the bus or better yet, take the subway. It’s faster. Lisa enters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 21A. 31 MS. WHITMAN (CONT’D) Lisa, fill Lee in on some basics please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Hi. 22. 31

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So, what is your job?

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: That doesn’t concern you. She does everything you don’t do. Of course. 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Lee is sitting on the subway with a Bendels bag in her la She’s reading a book about Fanny Brice. A LITTLE GIRL (7 years old) is standing in front of her, staring at her. Lee tries to ignore her but eventually lo up at the kid. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you a man?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Are you a gargoyle? The STARTLED MOTHER yanks at her daughter’s arm and pulls away. Lee goes back to her book. 33 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR - SAME DAY 33 Lisa is showing Lee how to record things in a log book.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: So you have to account for how you spend your time each day. If you make a phone call for her, write it here. If you make a phone call for yourself, write it there.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is this for real?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Everything I do, I write down? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 23. 33

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Going to the bathroom? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (beat) You get paid at the end of each day, in cash. Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lisa goes to a drawer in the corridor and takes out two twenty dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (off Lee’s disappointed face) Ms. Whitman pays what she thinks is fair, considering it’s under the table.

dialogues.speaker: A34
dialogues.text: Across the street, Lee stands in a phone booth as Jack ha her the sheet of paper from the night before, with the li of names from the buzzer. She puts in a quarter and dials As Lee speaks, they watch the front of the store.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (in thick Long Island accent) Hello, I’m looking for the tall guy, the book buyer, Glen. Oh, hello, thank god! This is Lillian Schuster from the fourth floor. There’s an emergency! The building’s on fire. We’re all outside! Oh my god it’s horrible!... no, they’re not letting us back in! You better come over and get your dog! I see flames coming out of your window right now! I think I hear the poor thing squealing! They watch as Glen frantically trips out of the store and runs up the street. They crack up, gratified.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That was very enjoyable.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thoroughly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 23A.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You do such a good voice! Lee reaches into her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve got no jingle in my jeans. You got a token? Put out, Jack looks through his change. 34 INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - WAITING ROOM - DAY 34 Lee sits with other PET OWNERS in the waiting room. A YOU GIRL is with her DOG.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: (to a Lady with cat carrier) She’s so cute!

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED LADY
dialogues.text: Unless she’s shredding the side of my sofa.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, I guess that’s not good.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Cats. Not for me. Lee leans over and pets the Old Man’s OLD DOG.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’s a good boy, isn’t he? The best.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED LADY
dialogues.text: He looks sick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 24. 34

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Just needs a shot. He could use a bath but he doesn’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED LADY
dialogues.text: Pearl here isn’t going to like getting declawed but it’s

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s cruel to de-claw your cat. Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s like walking on glass for the rest of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: I haven’t heard that.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED LADY
dialogues.text: Well, tell that to my ten thousand dollar Ligne Roset.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I would, except it’s an object. The receptionist, Rachel, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Jersey Israel? Lee gets up and goes to the counter. RACHEL (CONT’D) Hi, Ms. Israel. Are you’re able to pay for the tests?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m here. (beat) You shouldn’t de-claw.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s harmless. Really. Lee takes a deep breath. 35 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S BEDROOM - ANOTHER DAY 35 Lee is writing a letter by hand for Ms. Whitman while she dictates from her bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 25. 35

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: The event was clearly a success and I couldn’t have succeeded without you. Your help and advice have been very generous and LEE Are you sure you want to use success two times? Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Clearly a success and succeeded.’

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, did I ask you for advice?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I just thought MS. WHITMAN I have a Masters degree in English, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And I’m a published author, Ms. Whitman. Whitman sighs deeply, thinking she’s being mocked.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Can we continue, please? Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Now I lost my train of thought. 36 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S LIBRARY - LATER THAT DAY 36 Lee is at the large bookshelf organizing and dusting the books. Surprised, she finds her own book MISS TALLULAH BANKHEAD, and pulls it out. Lisa enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Ms. Whitman doesn’t like anyone touching the books. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 26. 36

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How can I possibly organize and clean them if I cannot touch them?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I mean, you know what I mean. Ms. Whitman enters.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Lee, I need you to balance Natalie’s checkbook.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Your teenager.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve opened an account for her. She needs to learn responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: By me balancing her checkbook? Ms. Whitman looks at her, coldly considering her.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: If you want to borrow a book, simply ask before handling it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I mentioned that I was a published author. This is my book. Ms. Whitman inhales.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: I get the sense you’re not very happy here. I’m giddy.

dialogues.speaker: MS. WHITMAN
dialogues.text: You’re sarcastic and impolite. (beat, leaving) You’ll be paid for your time here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: If you can call it pay. 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa hands Lee two twenties and then slams the door. 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Ms. Whitman is holding the Tallulah Bankhead book, lookin with shock at Lee’s photo on the back. 39 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS 39 Lisa silently reads Lee’s log, mouth agape. 1:45 - 1:48. Took a dump and scratched my cunt. 3:22 - 3:26. Got fired. 3:27-3:28 Took another dump. Forgot to flush. Oops. 40 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 40 Lee enters the bar, looks around, and sees Jack a few sto away. She sits away from him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I rang you and you didn’t ring me back. Should I take it personally?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’d never get out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And lucky for me, you did. She’s somewhat entertained by him, in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m coming to sit next to you because I’m not very good at social cues. He moves next to her and Lee speaks to Craig, the bartend

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Scotch, water, Craig. And I’ll buy his next one.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, things are looking up!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Got shit-canned again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 28. 40

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That is exactly the reason I don’t get a job. (beat) You’re a successful writer. Aren’t you writing a book?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: On Fanny Brice. Who?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just the greatest vaudeville comedian of her time. You sure you’re a fag?

dialogues.speaker: A41
dialogues.text: Lee crosses into the large library. 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 The table is covered with articles and books. Lee is taki notes on a pad. She separates some papers and finds TWO TYPED LETTERS SIG BY FANNY BRICE. Her eyes widen. She looks around - to let someone know the letters don’t belong here - and then she changes her mind. She reads them with a kind of secret thrill. She glances around the room, relieved that no one is look her way. Quickly, she drops the letters into her canvas b 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Anna greets Lee as she enters the shop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, hi Lee. Nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You as well.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How’ve you been? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 29. 42

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve discovered that my cousin Sydney was in possession of this delightful bonne bouche. I thought you might be interested in it. She hands her one of the Fanny Brice letters, protected i plastic.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Fanny Brice. One of my favorites.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (finally!) I’ve been working on a new biography on her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What a funny coincidence then, that your cousin had this! (beat) Well, she’s much more your style than Estee Lauder.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Right? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Didn’t she say “Wrong is for other people.”? I love that.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (impressed) She did. Anna smiles and looks to the letter. LEE (CONT’D) Well, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I believe I could sell this. (beat) I could offer you seventy five. Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I could pay more for better content. It’s a bit bland, is all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 30. 42

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (glancing at the letter) True. Anna goes to write a check. LEE (CONT’D) Would you be able to pay cash?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Let me see if I have enough. (she checks a drawer) I’m glad to hear you’re writing another book! I’ll be the first to buy it. Did you hear Tom Clancy is going to get paid 3 million dollars to write more rightwing macho bullshit? the literary world?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? That blowhard is getting paid three million dollars? Anna is taken aback by Lee’s reaction. LEE (CONT’D) Everyone thinks they can be a writer, I guess. Oh to be a white male, who doesn’t know he’s full of crap, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh - I totally agree. Why do we celebrate the famous over the actual great writers of our day? The culture is dying. Lee is struck by how Anna is saying exactly what she feel

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: My sentiments exactly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (beat) I’ve tried to write a little. Short stories. And I know better than to presume they’re any good. (beat) I can’t believe I just admitted that! I’m sure they’re terrible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 31. 42

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Maybe they are, maybe they’re not. (beat) Let me take a look. Really?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll be honest.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I believe you! 43 INT. MARJORIE’S OFFICE - LATER THAT DAY 43 Lee barges into Marjorie’s office, leaving the door open.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I hear they got Tom Clancy three million dollars to write some more red-baiting propaganda?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Lee - I’ve had too long a morning already for this.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’s a fraud.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: What is your point?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He was drinking sherry at your party. No self-respecting writer would drink sherry.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Oh lord, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I need an advance for my Fanny Brice book. I need you to get me ten thousand dollars. I am months behind in my rent and my cat is sick and isn’t that why I have an agent?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (losing her cool) I can’t get you an advance like that, Lee. I just can’t. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 32. 43

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Give me one reason why that cocky shit would get three million dollars and you can’t get me ten thousand? Are you that bad of an agent?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (calling to her assistant in the adjoining room) Toni, can you please close the door? Ms. Israel and I have some sensitive business to discuss. The door closes behind Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’d hate for her to hear a grown up conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: I’ll give you three reasons. Number one Tom Clancy’s famous.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well here we go.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: I can’t get an advance for you because nobody has ever heard of you- you’ve written some successful biographies, sure, and you disappeared behind your subjects, but that means nobody knows who you are!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Because I did my job!

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Number two - Tom Clancy goes on every radio show, on Larry King, to every book signing and he plays the game, he hobnobs. Meanwhile, you’ve burned every bridge I’ve made for you. You’re impossible to work with and everybody knows it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: See, this feels beside the point. If I’m a good writerMARJORIE Number three- nobody wants a book about Fanny Brice. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 33. 43

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing new and sexy about Fanny Brice. Nobody will give you a ten DOLLAR advance for a book about Fanny Brice! Lee is shocked, but also kind of impressed. She sits.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I had a book on the New York Times best seller list. That has to count for something.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: I’ve known you a long time, Lee. It hurts me to have to say this all to you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Tell me what to do, then, Marjorie. I have to do something. I will take anything! Magazine pieces, crackerbox copy. I’m not trying to get rich here, I’m just trying to survive.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: The way I see it you have two optionseither you become a gets along with others. You put on a clean shirt, you stop drinking, you say “please” and “thank you”LEE Oh you’ve got to be fucking kidding meMARJORIE Which doesn’t seem like it’s going to happen. OR - you take the time to become a name that people know, and then maybe, maybe I will be able to get you paid again.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How the hell am I supposed to do that? I’m a 51 year old woman who likes cats more than people. That’s not “hot and sexy”, as you’d say.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Write your book. Something for you, in your voice.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Well- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 34. 43

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: You’ve been saying you were going to do it for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, I would love to, that sounds delightful Marjorie, but I need money yesterday. I have to pay my bills. We don’t all have ex-husbands who left us a classic six on the park. Marjorie shakes her head, offended and exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: You can be an asshole if you’re famous. You can’t be unknown and be such a bitch, Lee. (then) Nobody is going to pay for the writer Lee Israel right now. So I suggest you find another way to make your living. Lee thinks about this. 44 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 44 Lee sits in front of her typewriter. She stares at the bl page, contemplating. She types: “This is me sitting down fucking write”. And stops. She glances at the other Fanny Brice letter sitting nearby, taunting her. She picks up the Fanny Brice letter and compares the typeface. It matches. She zips the sheet from the typewriter and rolls the Fann Brice letter into it. She scrolls down and adds a P.S. P.S. I have a new Grandkid, and he got my old nose. Do I have to leave him an extra something for repairs? She smiles, and then heartily laughs to herself. It’s a g joke. 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 Anna and Lee are sitting in the back of the store. Anna i laughing, reading the letter. She’s not aware of Lee’s anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Who writes like that? Only Fanny Brice, right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 35.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (pleased with herself) It’s a good one, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, my father would enjoy this. He relished a good self-depreciating joke. (beat) This was his store. Oh?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: For forty years. He passed away.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And now it’s yours.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yup. I kind of grew up in here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A few of the shops are hanging on. But Barnes and Noble is killing us. It’s probably good he’s not around to see it. He hated chain stores. His customers were very loyal, though. They would sit right here and drink scotch together. She reaches into a drawer and removes a bottle of scotch. Then runs off and returns with two glasses. Yes? Indeed. ANNA (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Anna pours and they toast.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can definitely sell this one for a lot more. I mean, the P.S. makes it priceless! (beat) How’s three fifty? 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 36. INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 46 Rachel has laid out three bottles of prescription pills i front of Lee.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: One of each, two times a day, in her food. The infection will probably go away in a day or two, but keep giving her the pills, they’ll help stabilize her. 47 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY - NIGHT 47 Lee is handing Andrei cash in his doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: Keep it coming, Ms. Israel. I don’t want to be the bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And here. Your mother needed milk. She gives Andrei a grocery bag. Adina appears.

dialogues.speaker: ADINA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ms. Israel.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re very welcome. Your hair looks good today. Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: You still having insect problems?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s awful. Dead flies everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: I’m going to take care of it. 48 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - NIGHT 48 Lee and Jack are drunk, spending the last of her earnings

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So what did you do this time? (off her confusion) I’m assuming you got sacked from yet another tedious job? Is that not why we are drinking? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 37. 48

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: This is a celebratory session of drinking, not a wallowing one.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s hard to tell the difference with you. No offense. Lee smirks.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve figured out a way to pay my bills without shovelling shit. It’s a good feeling.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, chin-chin! (he lifts his glass) You going to tell me how? Lee smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’d be too scandalized.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh MY! You clearly don’t know me well.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No. Some things are better kept to oneself. (then) Even if it is sort of brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh come on, spill! Lee looks around. She can’t keep it inside any longer.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Alright fine, can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I have no one to tell. All my friends are dead. This registers on Lee for a moment, then passes.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Quite by accident, I’ve found myself in a rather criminal position. Jack perks up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 38. 48

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can’t fathom what crime you are possibly committing. Except a crime of fashion, of course.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve been embellishing documents, if you will.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (intrigued, conspiratorially) Are you forging checks?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (excited, topping him) No. Literary letters! From famous writers. Jack is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So... Not checks? Not money? Just letters?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) You don’t understand the elite world of collectable literary artifacts.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I suppose I don’t. (sarcastically) How thrilling. You’re forging pieces of paper that go where? Libraries?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I sell them to collectors.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How much are you getting for them?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have told you. What a waste of a secret. I could have told a rock and gotten a better response.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What if you get caught?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I can’t get caught. Fools get caught. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 39. 48

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ve heard that before! (then) Am I the first person you’ve told?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You aren’t the only one without friends.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t you have a girlfriend or something? Some bit of fluff? Some lovely hanger-on?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That would be you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I remember you had someone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We broke up. She was a pain in my ass. Why?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She wanted things.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Like what? Money?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She wanted me to listen to all her problems, and be closer with her friends. Things like that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The nerve. (then) I haven’t been in a relationship for so long. It’s really hard to meet someone at my age. I’m losing my hair. He pulls back his hair to show her where it’s receding.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s the reason.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (beat) I’m thinking about getting my eyes done. He turns to her, square on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Should I? 40. 48 JACK (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Should I? They both stare at each other’s faces. (beat) No point. Asshole. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 A LARGE BANNER READS “P.S.3 GREENWICH VILLAGE ANTIQUARIAN BOOK FAIR” Lee and Jack pass under it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh god, I hope they serve booze.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) They most certainly do not serve booze. But maybe you can find some coke. Lee and Jack wander around the packed, noisy event, takin all in. Dealers at tables and DOZENS OF PEOPLE shopping. Crazy people, normal people, all kinds.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You’re going to figure who to forge?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t forge. I wrote a couple of hot sentences. (beat) We’re people watching.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) Yeah, right. Jack is drawn to a table covered in SIGNED HEAD SHOTS OF MOVIE STARS. He picks up a photo of young LAURENCE OLIVIE JACK (CONT’D) Oh my god - I loved him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 41. 49

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s available.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Isn’t he dead? He’d be very old by now. Lee glares at him. JACK (CONT’D) Don’t look at me like that. So I don’t keep up. So what. They approach a table named HARRY’S COLLECTIBLES. Jack lifts a signed autograph and looks at the VENDOR, HA JACK (CONT’D) How much is this?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How do you know he really signed it?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (defensive) It’s authenticated. By whom.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) By an authenticator.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Who authenticates the authenticator? Harry turns away to another customer. Lee and Jack wander away, laughing. Lee wanders and Jack follows, collecting the business car off the tables that sell signed letters. She smiles at th Vendors, perusing their wares.

dialogues.speaker: THE ARGOSY BOOK SHOP TABLE
dialogues.text: Lee and Jack are looking over the signed letters and autographed first editions. A woman, NELL, is the vendor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 42. 49

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: Are you looking for anyone in particular?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Not really. You have a wonderful collection. Lee is looking at a letter by NOEL COWARD.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: Such a hoot, isn’t he? Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: Oh, take a look at this beauty. I just got a hold of this one - Dorothy Parker. She hands Lee a framed letter by Dorothy Parker. Lee read

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I was born thirty years too late.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: I feel the same way.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How much is that?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We’re not buying today. Just looking.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: No problem. I’m asking six hundred. WOW.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lee blanches, embarrassed by him. She glances down at the letter again.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: Just in case you are tempted, make sure you do your homework. Not all of the other dealers are as discerning as we are. Oh?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 43. 49

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: Some care more than others about getting the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just so we know, who should we be looking out for? NELL looks around and points to a MAN, 40, some distance away. He stands behind a table that has many customers.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: That one. Not sure, but I’d stay away from him.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you so much for the advice. Take care.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: NELL moves off to help someone else and they walk on.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You need to keep your mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What did I do? 50 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - LOBBY - AFTERNOON 50 She and Jack enter her building and find Andrei and the EXTERMINATOR.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: Oh, good. He just did the third floor. Let’s go to your place.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Finally. These flies are making me crazy. 51 EXT. LEE’S APARTMENT DOOR - MOMENTS LATER 51 Lee unlocks her front door and walks inside. Jack, Andrei the exterminator follow behind. Whoa!

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Andrei and the exterminator immediately turn around and w out. Jack stands next to Lee, frozen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 44. 51 EXTERMINATOR (CONT’D) I’m not going in there. It smells horrible. He looks around at the messy place. Dirty dishes, garbage newspapers, and apparently, a terrible smell.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What? Let me show you the dead flies. They’re everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Sorry, lady. I’ll come back when it’s cleaned up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: What’s going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Nothing! I’ll clean up. They walk away. Jack looks at Lee with pity. She’s humiliated, but doesn’t understand the problem.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (gently) It smells very bad.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You think I’m deaf? I heard them. Jesus. I’ll do a little straightening! She shuts the door on him, turns around and surveys the place.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (through the door) You want me to help you? Come on, I’ll help you. 52 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Lee crouches down and looks under her bed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s in here. There, along with a million dust bunnies, is a month’s wo of cat shit. 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 45. INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - AFTERNOON 53 Lee is dragging a broom across the cat shit. Jack holds a garbage bag open and she dumps it all in. 54 INT. LEE’S KITCHEN - LATER 54 Drinking wine, she washes dishes and wipes dead flies ont her sponge. Jack sweeps the living room. 55

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 55 56 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 56 A drunk Lee sits on her bed on the phone. Hello? MARIE’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hello? Elaine? MARIE’S VOICE Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Who is this? MARIE’S VOICE You called me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What’s your name? MARIE’S VOICE What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Harrison Ford! (alt: Elaine Stritch) Who the hell are you? Lee slams down the phone. Jack appears in the doorway eat take-out fried chicken. She gives him a mischievous look she picks up the phone again. She dials. LEE (CONT’D) Hello, is Marjorie there? It’s Lee Israel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 46. 56 MARJORIE’S ASSISTANT’S VOICE I’m sorry, she’s unavailable right now.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I see. Will you leave word that I called? Thank you. She hangs up and then dials again. Hello? MARJORIE’S ASSISTANT’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (in different voice) Good evening, I have Nora Ephron. MARJORIE’S ASSISTANT’S VOICE Certainly. One moment. MARJORIE’S VOICE Nora, hello!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (in Nora’s voice) Is this a good time? MARJORIE’S VOICE Of course. So wonderful to hear from you!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (in her own voice) Star-fucker! Is that one word or two? Lee slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You sure you should be doing that?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Life’s short.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You’re so good! You should be on vaudeville! She smirks at him. JACK (CONT’D) Who’s Elaine?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Not your business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who’re you going to call now? 46A. 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Walking down the street and referring to a slip of paper an address scribbled, Lee finds what she’s searching for: shop full of junk and old typewriters in the window. 58 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY Books on Noel Coward cover the table. his biographies and taking notes. 59 58 Lee is reading one of INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER 59 She shuffles through some of her very old notebooks and b of blank stationary. For once she’s glad she doesn’t thro anything away. Pleased, she’s unearths some very old, yellowed typing paper. 60 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER At her desk, Lee inserts the sheet of paper into one of t newly purchased typewriter and rolls it in. She opens a nearby book for reference. It contains a repr of a Noel Coward letter. She measures the letter carefull and how he spaces his words.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (counting out loud) One two three four five spaces, fifteen space indent. She turns to the typewriter and pauses. Then she thoughtfully begins to type on the blank sheet. LEE’S VOICE OVER My dear Billy, I fear I must decline your invitation as this weekend heralds the arrival of Marlene. Lee smiles for the first time in a long time. LEE’S VOICE The canny old Kraut remains one of my most cherished friends, despite her predisposition to whining ad nauseam about her ageing process, as though she were the first gorgeous lady undone by Father Time... 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 48. INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - ANOTHER DAY 61 We hear Lee’s voice as she attempts to trace Noel Coward’ signature. LEE’S VOICE Dear Sidney, I had no idea you knew Dottie Parker. A tragic loss but she has been dying for decades. Whether it was drink or chemistry or character, she was unable after a time to write anything and that made her sere and infinitely pathetic. My own friends are dropping like flies and I am thankful of late when they live through lunch. Having a difficult time tracing, she tries to simply copy but it looks shaky. She looks around her place and takes an interest in her ancient TV set. 62 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - MOMENTS LATER 62 She is disemboweling it. 63 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - JUST AFTER 63 Lee has placed the shell of the TV over a small lamp with shade. The bare bulb illuminates the screen and makes for perfect light box. Lee places the original signature in the book on the scre and then her own letter. Easily and with flourish, she fo Noel Coward. It appears completely genuine. She signs another letter a stares at her work. 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 Lee sits on the subway, anxiously holding an old brief ca She’s dressed up a bit. 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 Lee enters the charming store. The owner PAUL, 60’s and nerdy, turns to see her. Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 49. 65

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. I’m aware that you sell memorabilia and first editions, as well as typed letters signed?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, all of it. What can I do for you? She removes the Coward letters from her briefcase, encase a plastic sheath.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Would you be interested in these? Paul takes the letters and reads them, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: These are wonderful! Yes, I’d be very interested.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I have a cousin who was a collector. He asked me to sell some of his treasures so he can afford his early bird specials in Palm Beach.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hard to find letters that have a real taste of the author’s personality, but these do just that! Lee can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yes, I thought so myself. Very clever man.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can give you two hundred for them. How does that sound?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry. I’m afraid I could get at least double that elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (impressed) Okay. You’re probably right. Name your price.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think four hundred would be fair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 (beat) Okay. 50. 65

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Paul starts to write out a check.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Would you happen to have cash? My cousin closed out his accounts - it’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think I’ve got it. He hands her the cash. PAUL (CONT’D) Please, anything else you come across bring it in. I have come in frequently. Or I call them if I have something I know they’ll like.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: In fact, I have a buyer who actually knew Mr. Coward. He’s going to love this!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Really? (tense) Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: A66
dialogues.text: Lee walks with purpose, feeling the fresh victory of her recent sale. 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 Lee enters. 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Lee meets Jack - who looks tired and disheveled. She join him in a booth and hands him a copy of one the letters sh just sold.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re looking at one month’s rent. Jack reads a bit of the letter and looks at her, confused (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 50A. 67

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who’s Marlene? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 51. 67

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (pronounced correctly) Marlene! Why am I even showing this to you. She snatches it back, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How much did you get?!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Four hundred for two.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A little more than I just made. What?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I sold a little coke.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (appalled) Right here? To whom!?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Some fool. It was mostly laxative. He just left.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Keep me out of, and away from your seedy dealings.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That’s funny, coming from a woman who just sold someone a piece of paper for four hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: A piece of paper? It was literary genius, you dope. He couldn’t believe how witty they were. The WAITER with a name tag (KURT) comes up.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (flirting) Hello ladies.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I resent that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 52. 67

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (flirting back) Is the cinnamon roll sweet, or too sweet?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s perfect. If you don’t like it, I’ll eat it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll have coffee. Kurt is about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And can you warm it up?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Of course I can.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) How are you going to eat it with his dick in your mouth?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: First things first.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re shameless.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He started it. (excited) So, now we both have some money. What should we do?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gamble? Drink? Shop? I don’t suppose you dance?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Unlike you, I actually try to put my money to good use. Like buying food and securing shelter.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I just thought we could do something. Life is dreary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 53. 67

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I know what we can do that’ll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Did you just say ‘fun?’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 Lee sits in the middle of the floor, thirty cats surround on scratching posts and cat trees and elaborate cat house It’s either someone’s idea of heaven or someone’s idea of Hell. Jack stands back, as an employee, PRISCILLA 20s, wa by the door.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You’ve got to be kidding me. This is your answer to dreary

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Have a good cuddle. PRISCILLA leaves, closing the door. Lee, who has been her before, starts to say hello to different cats as they jum down and greet her. She sits on the carpet and they climb her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A dyke who likes cats. How original.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sit down. You allergic?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not physically.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Then sit down. Jack does as he’s told. Reluctant at first, the cats go t him and he blanches. Slowly, he becomes comfortable and p them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Do they know you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No. But I’ve been coming here for years. (beat) Don’t spread it around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 54. 68

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I won’t. I’d be too embarrassed for you. (whispers) I hate cats!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve only brought one other person here. It was kind of our “thing.”

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh... Elaine?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She picked out Jersey for me and brought her home.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You two stay in touch?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) I think she might be living with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought you dumped her. It’s how you made it sound, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, it was messy. I don’t know. (beat ) I’m not exactly the picture of mental health, if you haven’t noticed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (teasing) What on earth could you be referring to? Lee puts her face close to a cat on the floor. JACK (CONT’D) Okay I’ve seen your idea of celebration. Tonight can I show you mine? Please? Lee is wary. 69 INT. EIGHTY-EIGHT’S PIANO BAR - NIGHT 69 Lee and Jack enter the upscale gay piano bar, which is dripping with history. They head to a small round table. the piano, is a true performer, one of the last of her br who sings the classics, with witty reparte between songs. She’s singing “Goodnight Ladies”. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 55. 69

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: There aren’t go-go dancers, but I love this place. Lee takes it all in, as they settle in to a small table. can’t read if Lee hates this place or not. JACK (CONT’D) We don’t have to stay long. Can we just have one drink though?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No. I like it. It’s good. Jack is pleased. Lee lets herself get swept away by the music, which continues over the next scenes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Scotch and soda? Lee nods. He gets up to get them drinks. From the bar he looks back and sees Lee swaying just barely to the music. closes her eyes, enjoying this moment. He smiles to himse 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Lee is chatting with Anna as she looks over a freshly typ Noel Coward letter. They’re sitting at the table drinking scotch. A few CUSTOMERS browse the shop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: My father was a huge Noel Coward fan. I can practically hear his voice. It’s so him.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (pointing to the letter) This line here is especially clever, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful. I’m especially fond of his writing. Dorothy Parker as well. Caustic wit, you know?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Caustic wit is my religion.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can’t pull it off, but I admire those who can. You certainly can. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 56. 70

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t help too well in the relationship department.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Ah. I’m sure that’s not true. (beat) You have family?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (laughing) As in relatives.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, actually.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That’s too bad.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Relationships are complicated. I generally try to avoid them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is it possible?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: If you work at it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Okay. Shall we settle up? They walk to the counter. A curious customer, CHARLES, co over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: What are you buying? Anna proudly shows the letter. CHARLES (CONT’D) Is this real? Anna looks to Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I should say so!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: To think his pen touched this paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 57. 70 He reads the letter. CHARLES (CONT’D) A gem. (to Lee) Give her a good price. Lee tries to hide her pleasure. The man wanders off to browse.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (considering) Three hundred? Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Anna goes to the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I know. Cash. She hands Lee the money and writes out a receipt. ANNA (CONT’D) This has my number - I mean the store’s number (shy) If you’re ever in the neighborhood and you know, want to get a drink or a coffee sometime.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sounds good. I would like that. 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 The YOUNG CLERK holds up a piece of stationary monogramme DOROTHY PARKER, along with a Hollywood address. He hands to Lee.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Came out well, don’t you think? Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You didn’t want a watermark, right?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Correct. I find them tacky. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 58. 71

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Okay, Miss Parker, that will be thirty five fifty. She looks up, startled, then smiles. She reaches for her purse. 72 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 72 Lee is writing on a typewriter labeled “DOROTHY PARKER,” the phone rings. Placed around the room are typewriters labeled “NOEL COWARD,” “EDNA FERBER,” “TENNESSEE WILLIAMS Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Is Lee Israel there?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: This is she.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: This is Alan Schmidt from East Village Books. I heard you have a collection of some impressive letters and I was hoping I could get a look.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (guarded) Where do you work?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I own East Village Books. You think you might have any Louise Brooks? I got a lot of old timers around here who collect a strange variety of memorabilia. But I got no merchandise.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Louise Brooks... I’ll have to go through what I have.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Great. Come by as soon as you do. They hang up. Strange phone call. After a beat, she write LOUISE BROOKS on a label and then returns to her writing. LEE’S VOICE Dear Joshua -- Alan told me to write and apologize. I have a hangover that is a real museum piece; (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 59. 72 LEE’S VOICE (CONT'D) I’m sure that I must have said something terrible. To save me this kind of exertion in the future, I am thinking of having little letters runoff, saying: ‘Can you ever forgive me? Dorothy.’ -But until I do that: Can you ever forgive me? Dorothy. We see more labeled typewriters: “FANNY BRICE” and “MARLE DIETRICH.” Lee beams as she types, pleased with herself. 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Anna and Lee are sitting at a small table, chatting and drinking. Anna lifts her drink to toast Lee.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: To Fanny Brice, Noel Coward, and Dorothy Parker! May their brilliance live on! They clink and drink. ANNA (CONT’D) And to Lee. A brilliant writer who happens to still be alive!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s negotiable.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (beat) Wouldn’t it be incredible if once you’ve passed on, people were selling your letters?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I want that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Because. Most of us mortals just disappear. This way - you still kind of exist.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: When I die - who cares. As long as someone feeds my cat.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’ll feed your cat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Thank you. 60. 73
