dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Anna hands her a napkin and finds a pen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I want to be the first. Come on. Immortalize yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Just sign it. Lee picks up the pen. ANNA (CONT’D) (beat) Gosh, calling a hangover a museum piece. Brilliant! Lee freezes, does she mean her? ANNA (CONT’D) Oh, I wish I could’ve met Dorothy Parker. Relief.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s hard finding someone who knows who she was. Lee signs the napkin and Anna takes it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (reading) Humphrey Bogart? You’re no fun.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So I’ve been told.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Have you ever written about yourself?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Don’t think I’d find myself that interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I would. You should. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 61. 73

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re very flattering, Anna. Anna reaches into her bag and pulls out an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I’m doing this, but here’s one of my stories.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You brought it with you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m an idiot, I know.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll give it a read.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’ve only taken a couple of classes so LEE Don’t worry about it. I’m honored. They look down at the menus and Anna puts on a pair of glasses. LEE (CONT’D) You wear glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Only recently.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I like them. They look good on you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure about the frames.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: They’re nice.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I used to have perfect vision. (smiles) Don’t you love getting older and watching your parts - fall apart!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re too young. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 62. 73

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hardly. I really thought I’d have more accomplished by this time in my life.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s why you need to drink more alcohol. (beat) I thought the shop was yours.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, I inherited it. Truth be told, it’s more pressure than I thought. Oh?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: My father took a lot of pride in it. Almost too much! He was very choosy and almost snobbish about his inventory. I try to live up to that - run it how he would run it. Silence. Lee has become more uncomfortable. She drinks quickly. ANNA (CONT’D) So, you’ve been here before?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Couple of times.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where did you grow up?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Woodside, Queens. My parents live in Florida, may they rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t have family.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I also have a ridiculous brother in New Jersey. You?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m an only child. I’m close with a few of my cousins, though.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, I have some cousins, I think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 63. 73

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Not into the family thing?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I like my alone time.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Not every second though. You’re here with me right now!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hey. I always need a drinking buddy. But Anna’s not sure if she likes that. 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 They come out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This was fun. I think I’m a little tipsy. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Takes a lot more than that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh no. Have I embarrassed myself? (beat) How did Dorothy say it? “Can You Ever Forgive Me?” Anna looks at Lee, and there’s a long silence. ANNA (CONT’D) What? Did I say something wrong? Lee, guilty, has a hard time looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, no. You didn’t do anything wrong. Oh. Good!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, this was very nice.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (shy) It was. So nice to make a new friend. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Indeed. 64. 74

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Awkwardly, they hug. LEE (CONT’D) (business like) Speak soon? (beat) And when I’ve read your story, I’ll let you know. I’m just pretty busy these days so I might not get to it right away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh, that’s okay. (beat) Good-night.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good-night. Lee turns and walks away. Anna stays there a second, tips and confused. 75 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 75 She lies in bed (next to Jersey) reading. After a moment she pulls Anna’s story from her bag and st to read it. She can’t do it. She tosses it and flips off light. 76 INT. LEE’S LIVING ROOM - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT 76 Having been awakened by banging on the door, Lee runs to She looks through the peephole and sees Jack with a bleed lip and a bruised face. 77 INT. LEE’S BATHROOM - NIGHT 77 Jack sits on the toilet with a washcloth on his face whil Lee searches the medicine cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You need a new shower curtain, you know.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You want to discuss decorating with me? Who beat you up? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 65. 77

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s my own fault. (beat) I didn’t have enough money and I didn’t know until after - until it was too late.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m not even going to try and understand that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I used to get away with so much. Do you think it will scar? She finds the hydrogen peroxide and attends to his wounds She stares at him. JACK (CONT’D) I couldn’t find my keys, I couldn’t get into my apartment. (beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And where is said apartment?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It was on 92nd. And then it was on 96th. And then... Lee leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You can sleep on my couch. He smiles, grateful. 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 The place is dusty and badly organized. Lee, holding the typewriter in its case, wanders down an aisle and notices piles of typewriter paper and stationery, stacked careles Some of it is yellowed and old. 80 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 80 Lee writes a letter on that very paper. The table is litt with books about Louise Brooks and papers covered with Le notes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 66. 80 LEE’S VOICE Dear Paul, Your friend Barry was absolutely accurate in his predicting that cheap Charlie Chaplin would write a vulgar book for vulgar people. Lee is smiling, enjoying herself. 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Lee enters the shop. 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 A dusty and crowded store. The owner, ALAN SCHMIDT (45) i behind the counter finishing up with a customer. (He also happens to be the man NELL pointed to at the book fair wh warning Lee). LEE’S VOICE The lies he tells about Paulette are understandable; she was a bitch in a ditch and he grew to hate her. Given the opportunity, I wouldn’t even fart in her direction!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: How can I help?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You called about Louise Brooks.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I certainly did. You’re Lee?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Ms. Israel. Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: They shake. ALAN (CONT’D) Whaddya got? Lee hands him a couple of letters, carefully encased. ALAN (CONT’D) These are beauts. (beat) Funny, how you happened to have them! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 67. 82

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I had to go through a lot of my cousin’s things, and there they were. They’re quite witty, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (reading) She had quite the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (tense, defensive) She had a very big personality.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Liked the ladies, I hear. (beat) This the real thing?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I assume so. He studies it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Anyway, most people will believe what you tell them. And they love this stuff. Personally, I don’t get it. (beat) How much you want for them?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Five hundred dollars seems fair. Two fifty.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m giving you a good deal.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (relenting) Four.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: All right. I’d prefer cash, if you got it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Of course I got it. As he gets the money - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 68. 82 ALAN (CONT’D) If you come across any more - especially if she mentions any other people - like Harry Cohn or Howard Hughes. I can always pay more for those. 83 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 83

dialogues.speaker: UP
dialogues.text: Of Lee signing several letters in different colored penci LEE’S VOICE Dear Bill, Finally, I got to see HELL’S lot of bad acting of course, Harlow literally glistens. I through it of how compelling Howard Hughes was -84

dialogues.speaker: ANGELS. A
dialogues.text: but Jean thought all the young

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 Lee hands letters to NELL, the woman she met at the convention, who looks them over suspiciously. 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 An OLD MAN counts out cash for Lee. LEE’S VOICE Dear Flora, I was never comfortable being viewed as a victim, despite Harry Cohn’s attempts. I would have burned in hell before sleeping with that fat-assed little Caesar. My cat has spit up hair-balls more attractive than him. 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 Alan Schmidt hands Lee a pile of cash. 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 And now another DEALER is handing Alan cash for some of L letters.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER DEALER
dialogues.text: Where’d these come from?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Some cranky dyke. Pretty good, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 69-70. 87 The other dealer shrugs, not caring. 88 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING/ANDREI’S DOOR - DAY Andrei is counting a handful of cash.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: All cash, huh? What are you now, a waitress? He looks at the bills and sees they’re large.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I robbed a bank. Andrei’s mother Adina, 80, appears in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: ADINA
dialogues.text: Ms. Israel.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Mrs. Ungur?

dialogues.speaker: ADINA
dialogues.text: Thank you for those cookies.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Those were good, weren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: ADINA
dialogues.text: Not as good as the chocolate Babka. But good.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll have to remember that. (beat, lightly) Tell your son to go easy on me, will you? Can’t kick an old dog out on the street, right? 88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 Lee and Jack sit at a small table. They’ve already got th drinks.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How have you gotten along for as long as you have?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Living here and there. Selling illegal substances, behaving imprudently. What? Unwisely.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t underestimate sparkly blue eyes and a little bit of street smarts - they go far in this city. Although I may be stretching their limits.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: But who did you want to be? What was your plan?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say. I always imagined I would figure it out as I went along. And for the most part, I have. I have no regrets.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That can’t be true.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You mean, why don’t I have some brilliant talent like you do for copying?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is that what you think I do? Copying? Let me tell you something. I’m a better Dorothy Parker than Dorothy Parker.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, cheers to that! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 71A. 89 They cheers.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s good writing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then everyone wins. What’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How on earth are you so imbecilic? Nobody knows it’s me. I do.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The FEMALE SERVER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SERVER
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ll have a burger, rare, with onions.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll have the same.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get the steak. You said you wanted a steak. You sure?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’ll have the steak.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why don’t you get a steak?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We came here to get you a steak. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SERVER
dialogues.text: Skirt or T-bone? Jack falters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 71B. 89

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’ll have the T-bone. (beat) And another round. 90 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER 90 Jack and Lee are in the living room. She opens a new bott of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I put on some music? She points to a stack of records and Jack goes to them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 72. 90

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Be careful. In fact, don’t touch them. She pours two glasses and hands one to him. LEE (CONT’D) What do you want to hear? She flips through her albums so Jack can see.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Something joyful. Dare I say, gay? She removes an album and puts it on (most likely it won’t joyful). JACK (CONT’D) Did you ever want to be famous? (beat) You know, like the people you write like. You’re as good as them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind getting my own table at The Palm. Believe me, I thought that by now I would have. (beat) You know I was only thirty two when my first book was published. I thought it would all be She gestures like an airplane going up... th goes sharply down.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I started out here His airplane up. JACK (CONT’D) And it’s just been His airplane goes down and down until Fuck ‘em. Fuck ‘em. JACK (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 72A. INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER Lee and Jack are both passed out, each on their own side the sofa. 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 73. INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 92 Lee extracts sheets of paper from the oven. They are perfectly curled and rumpled and are already typed on. Sh lays them out on the table. LEE’S VOICE My Dear Boy, I enjoyed our talk tremendously and was not the least bit upset about the article. 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 Jack paces and smokes as he waits. Kurt (the waiter he flirted with) comes outside, his shift over. LEE’S VOICE My professional demise has been gleefully predicted for years. Kurt greets Jack. LEE’S VOICE (CONT’D) But nonetheless I await the return of your ruby-red lips to blue Harbour, in the event my spirits should falter. Jack and Kurt disappear behind the restaurant for a “date LEE’S VOICE (CONT’D) Yours and very much anticipating, Noel. 94 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 94 As Lee expertly forges Noel Coward’s signature. She leans back in her chair, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This is quite something. 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 Paul and Lee look over the Noel Coward letter.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I thought so, too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, I think I already have a buyer for it. I’m going to call him as soon as you leave. (beat) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 74. 95

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I sent the Marlene Dietrich to Los Angeles - I got a request from a collector out there.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Wonderful. You guys do that - sell to other collectors?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. There’s a whole world of wheeling and dealing, most of which I don’t care to partake. A lot of characters in this line of work. (beat) Hey, for a while there we had the Hitler Diaries. Remember that? Criminal.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not everyone gets into this because they respect history and talent, if you know what I mean. She nods as he looks at her for what feels like a little long. 96 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 96 They enter. Jack flops on the couch and Lee’s goes into t kitchen. We see many more labeled typewriters throughout the apartment: ALDOUS HUXLEY, HUMPHREY BOGART, EUGENE O’NEILL, KURT WEIL EZRA POUND, MARGARET MITCHELL.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get your feet off the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (unsure) Really? Look at it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: This isn’t a flop house. She feeds her cat who walks over slowly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How old is that hairball, anyway? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Twelve. 75. 96

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That’s fuckin’ old. How many cat years is that He tries to count. Lee goes to the blinking phone ma presses PLAY. PAUL’S VOICE ON PHONE MACHINE This is Paul, from Armada. Ms. Israel, I was wondering if you could come in tomorrow. I have a couple of questions regarding the last Coward letter I purchased. She and Jack look at each other. Uh oh.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: PAUL’S VOICE Please come in or call as soon as you can. It’s important. 97 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 97 She lies awake in bed, unable to sleep. She rolls over an anxiously pushes the covers off of her. 98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 She’s trying to keep her cool as she stands at the counte waiting for Paul to finish with ANOTHER CUSTOMER. Finally he’s free. Hi Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know I’ve got the client that knew Noel Coward, and he said Mr. Coward would never have been as explicit as he was regarding his orientation. It was illegal in those days and - anyway. Apparently the letter was a fake. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 76. 98

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (concerned) I’m shocked. My uncle would be appalled.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean your cousin.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (flustered) Of course. My cousin was always rather avuncular toward me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (beat) I also got a call from Los Angeles, Lee. Seems one of your letters was quite the controversy at a convention out there. I hate to say it but your name has been put on a list. A list.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s like a red flag. People are on alert, that’s all. They won’t buy from you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Cousin Rodney had fakes? I’m sure he doesn’t know! I’ll refund whatever you’ve paid me PAUL I don’t want a refund. I’m all right. I just thought I’d let you know. 99 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - DAY 99 Panicked, Lee downs a drink. Jack is beside her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can sell to other dealers. There’s gotta be a lot of them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You are missing the point. I have so many letters! What am I going to do with them? Hours and hours of work. There’s a lot more money to be made. I just mastered Judy Holliday. They’re gorgeous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 77. 99

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think you mean Billie Holiday?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think you’re an idiot. I’m sure you can sell them. Nobody knows what you look like. 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 A FAX MACHINE WHIRS and the OLD MAN looks to it. 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 Another fax machine and a photo of Lee is slowly spit out Alan sees Lee. 102

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 NELL pulls the paper from her fax, seeing Lee’s face. 103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 Anna walks toward her fax machine as Lee’s face slowly appears. She pulls it out and reads the text.

dialogues.speaker: NOTICE FROM THE OFFICE OF THE FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGA
dialogues.text: Caution: possible forgeries being sold in New York City b one Lee Israel. If you have any information regarding thi please contact MARK SOLANAS, FBI. Anna, shocked and confused, stares at the picture. 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 Lee approaches a shop we’ve never seen before, holding a of letters. 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee enters and ARLENE turns to greet her.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: How can I She stops and steps back, turning cold. ARLENE (CONT’D) We don’t want your business here. Lee stands there, stunned. 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17

dialogues.speaker: 77A.
dialogues.text: 106 Lee enters the store. Looks empty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 78. 106

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hello? Alan? Alan appears from the back of the store, surprised and pleased to see Lee.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You got my message. Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (holding a file) I brought some wonderful Faulkner’s that I’ve unearthed.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Not why I called. Listen. The FBI has been in to see me. The FBI?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (beat) They asked me if I’d wear a wire. I’m not going to do that to you. I’m a good guy. And if they ask me to be a witness, I’ll lie. But you’re going to pay me five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I won’t rat you out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s very generous of you. I don’t have five thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) You’re a clever woman. More or less. Figure it out. You’re welcome. 107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 Lee and Jack walk.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How the hell am I going to pay that scum bag? I bet he knew all along. He probably turned me in so he could blackmail me! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 79. 107

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where am I going to get five thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nobody knows what I look like. Let me sell for you. She turns to him. JACK (CONT’D) And I get a cut.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Ten percent. Fifty.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh please. How is that fair? You can’t even spell CUP.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll be taking a huge risk. Besides, I owe you money. I could pay you back a lot faster.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So I pay you so you can pay me back, and Alan Schmidt pays you so I can pay him off. The irony is killing me. (beat) Twenty percent. Forty. 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 Jack nervously enters the shop.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: Hello! Welcome. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He goes to the counter. JACK (CONT’D) My granny just died and I found these in her closet. Would you be interested in something like this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 79A. 108

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: Edna Ferber!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You’ve heard of her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 80. 108

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’ve heard of her! She wrote that movie with James Dean.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I guess. I’m not up on these things.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: Your granny was a collector? Guess so! 109

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 109 Lee is in the kitchen when there’s a loud knock on the do It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: She opens up. Oh my god! JACK (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She bought all three! He shows her the cash. How much?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Six hundred dollars. I did it! I didn’t fuck up! 110

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 Alan is looking over some letters on the counter as Jack browses in the store.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh look at this! He holds up some strange statue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 81. 110 JACK (CONT’D) Such wonderful knick knacks.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: So your granny collected letters?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don’t know who these people are but I had a feeling they might be worth something.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: How’d you know I buy these sort of things? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) I can give you fifty dollars each.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I have a feeling I could do better. A store in Brooklyn offered me two hundred dollars for one!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you sell it to them, then?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I don’t like the boroughs. 111 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 111 The place is messier than usual. Lee looks like hell. Jac sitting down at the table opposite her, taking out some c

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I am good at this. You should see me. (beat) When was the last time you got outside?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How much did you get?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (boasting) The first place gave me six hundred dollars. The other guy gave me a thousand! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 82. 111

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You just got closer to paying that asshole back with his own money! He gave me a thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Was he suspicious?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not at all. Hell, I always did want to be an actor! Here. Lee watches him count out six hundred dollars. looks off to her. Something

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How much did you say he gave you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A thousand.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Then why is there eight hundred extra in your hand? What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re stealing from me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, what did I say? He gave me fourteen hundred. Isn’t that what I said?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You moron. You’re stealing from me and you don’t even know what you’re selling!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No. Lee, it was a mistake. Here. I’m sorry. He hands her more money.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’re selling literary TREASURES! One-ofa-kind, carefull It’s not just a piece of paper, it’s a portal to a better time and place when people honored the written word.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Okay I get it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 83. 111

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You need to respect what you’re selling. This is my work. Well... What?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I mean... You’re impersonating other people. Very well, I’m sure, but come on. Nobody is buying Lee Isreal letters. Lee is furious, but of course he has a point.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Steal from me again, I’ll fuckin’ kill you. 112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 Jack is inside the store talking to Anna. She is looking a Flannery O’Connor letter.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You never read A GOOD MAN IS HARD TO

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, but boy was she right!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This was your grandmother’s?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Found it in her suitcase. I assume it’s real. Do you think it’s real?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (studying it) Looks that way. (beat) But there have been some forgeries going around, I’ll need to get this authenticated before I can purchase it, if that’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh. I sincerely doubt - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 84. 112

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, I’m not saying you or your grandmother knew - it’s just a precaution. Jack looks down at the display case and sees Lee’s letter from Katherine Hepburn.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh look at that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Wonderful, isn’t it? Who’s Lee?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, an author she knew.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How much is it, if you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m asking eleven hundred.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, well worth it. 113 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 113 Jack and Lee eat take-out. Lee looks terrible (hung over, having slept).

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What a thief! I think she gave me less than two hundred for it! (beat) Flannery O’Connor?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She wants to have it authenticated.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Did you take it back?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I couldn’t. I didn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You left it with her? You idiot! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 85. 113

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stop calling me an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: They’re going send me to jail. Worse. The pillory. (beat) I’d kill myself first. (beat) You can’t do it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We can’t stop now.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Everyone is on high alert. (beat) I’ll never pay that schmuck off!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (beat) Maybe you should steal more real ones, like you did at first. And I’ll sell them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Finding those was a fluke.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where do the real letters go? Who has those?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Archives. Museums. And you need proof that you’re researching something. They don’t just let anyone in.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can get into archives. You’re a famous writer. You could steal those letters, copy them, replace your copies and sell the originals. Lee looks at him, like “where did all this come from?” JACK (CONT’D) In my sticky finger days I would find the thing I wanted, and it could only be things that came in boxes - like toothpaste, and I’d shop for a while with it in my basket. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 86. 113 JACK (CONT’D) Then, when no one was paying attention I’d take the toothpaste out of the box, slip it in my pocket and put my used one in the box. (beat) If they’re suspicious they come back to the shelf and see nothing is missing. 114 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - ANOTHER DAY 114 Lee is crouching down, looking at her cat under the couch

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You be a good girl. Jack comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He’ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She. It’s a SHE. She’s old. And she better be fine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just let me come with you. You gave her enough food for a month!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I need you here. She needs the pills.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But it was my idea!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you know you like the idea of actually living somewhere for a few days. Give her fresh water. And two pills twice a day. I will.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: The way I showed you? Mixing it in the food? Jack nods. Lee slowly stands up, grabs a packed duffel ba and a typewriter. LEE (CONT’D) Don’t snoop. And stay out of my bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 87. 114 She opens the door and slams it behind her. 115 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 115 He walks into her room and promptly flops on her bed. Aft second, he opens her night table drawer to snoop and shuf through some things before landing on a photograph. He lifts it to see - it’s of Lee and another woman, sitti at a picnic blanket in the park. 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee stares out the window. She next to her, a WOMAN is crying what to do. After a moment she on her headphones and turns on 117 116 is a ball of nerves. Seated softly. Lee notices, not sure reaches into her bag and puts her radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 FBI AGENT, SOLANAS 40s, stands with Anna. She’s showing h the Flannery O’Connor.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I told him I had to have it authenticated. He seemed pretty nervous.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I keep it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Of course not. (beat) Do you think he knew it was fake?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. But he might be working for someone who does. Anna’s face falls. Lee?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: If you think you can get her back in here, would you be willing to wear a wire? Anna thinks, torn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 I’m sorry. 118 88. 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 Lee walks through the grand campus. 119

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 A SECURITY GUARD surveys the room, Lee approaches the LIBRARIAN behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: YALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m doing an in-depth look at writers and alcoholism. Hence - Lillian Hellman. Here’s the contract with the publisher. Lee places a piece of paper in front of the woman. It’s a contract that Lee has clearly forged, but it looks real. LEE (CONT’D) Since there’s already a great deal written about her, I’m interested in the more personal, archival material. Any kind of correspondence, journals, diaries - would be ideal.

dialogues.speaker: YALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: I’ll give you what we’ve got. 120

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 In the back of the shop, Paul stands by as the FBI agent Solanas, who is joined by his partner AGENT DOYLE, showin him one of the Clara Blandick letters.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: Look familiar?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, I bought this one from her.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: (re: photo of Jack) What about this guy? Have you ever bought from him? Of course, Paul recognizes him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 88A. 120

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (realizing) They’re in it together. (beat) Right. As soon as I told her she was on the ‘no buy’ list, he started coming in. Such a shame. A smart woman.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DOYLE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a nut case. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 89. 120

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A talented nut case.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes at Doyle) She fooled every dealer and authenticator in New York. She’s smarter than you, you idiot. Doyle looks contrite. AGENT SOLANAS (CONT’D) (to Paul) Do you think you could get her back in here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: What about Jack Hock? Would you be willing to wear a wire? Paul considers.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (tickled) Just like in the movies. I always thought I would make an excellent detective.

dialogues.speaker: A121
dialogues.text: 121 Lee sifts through Lillian Hellman’s personal letters, all signed by the author. She removes a notebook, and while pretending to take note begins to copy the letters word for word. Lee turns, feeling like she’s being watched. Sure enough, security guard is eyeing her. She smiles and he looks awa Lowering her head, she slowly and very carefully tries he hand at the signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122-123 124 Working on a large glass of scotch, Lee is spread out all over the room with a light box, an old manual typewriter many papers on Lillian Hellman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CYEFM
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17
124 Seated at the desk, she is meticulously typing one of two Lillian letters on stationary that looks identical to wha she saw in the library. When she’s finished she practices signature. 125

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 Lee is in bed with another glass of scotch. She gets under the covers and picks up the motel phone an dials. Hello? MARIE’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. Elaine? MARIE’S VOICE No.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is she there? MARIE’S VOICE No, would you like to leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Lee Israel. Oh. (rude) MARIE’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Who’s this? MARIE’S VOICE This is Marie.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, okay Marie, can you please tell her I called? Same number. Thank you. She hangs up, distraught. 126 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 126 Jack is entertaining KURT at Lee’s apartment. Kurt is recklessly searching through her record collection. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 91. 126

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You’ve got good taste. But they’re in pretty bad shape. How long have you lived here?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (starting the record) Oh, forever.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Ever think about cleaning some of the junk out?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I might for the right man. What’s your place like? Kurt glides around the apartment inspecting it.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: A lot cleaner! What is all this? Why do you collect typewriters?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s too complicated to explain. It’s for my work. I don’t bring many people to my home. It’s my safe space. I’m very private. Kurt glances at the upended TV set/light box.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Guess you don’t watch a lot of TV.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Rots the brain. I don’t believe in it. I’m a reader. This makes Kurt smile. Jersey the cat wanders over.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Well hello little kitty! You look like death! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 92. 126

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t say that!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: So, what have you got? Jack goes to his bag and retrieves a joint and a little v of coke.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Little coke, little dope and little old me.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Let’s get this party started. 127 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - MORNING 127 Jack and Kurt, under the covers, are asleep in Lee’s bed. Jack wakes and drags himself out of bed wearing only his boxers, he flings on Lee’s ratty robe. 128 INT. LEE’S KITCHEN - MORNING 128 He opens two capsules and mixes the contents into a bowl food for Jersey, which she eats.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh thank god. He goes back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: A129
dialogues.text: Lee walks through the grand campus. 129

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129 The librarian is at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good morning. The Lillian Hellman box I was working on yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: YALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Ah yes, a book on drunk authors. Who else are you going to be writing about?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (checking her watch) You know what, I’ve got to catch a bus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 92A. 129

dialogues.speaker: YALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: (put off) Of course. I’ll get what you need.

dialogues.speaker: A130
dialogues.text: 130 Lee at the table, again going through the Lillian Hellman papers. As soon as the security guard looks away, Lee replaces the original letters with the forgeries. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 93. 130 Slowly, she slips the originals into her tall boot and th looks up to find the librarian glaring at her. Has she been caught? They both stare. Nobody breathes. Le smiles. Having been previously snubbed, the woman smirks looks away. Heart pounding, Lee rises, picks up the boxes and heads t the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Here you go! Sorry for the rush. I just get overly anxious when I’m traveling.

dialogues.speaker: YALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: (softening) Oh, of course. I do, too. (beat) Find what you needed?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And then some. Thank you for your help. Lee walks to the exit and is stopped by the guard, who as to look in her large bag. The librarian opens the box, suspicious. She stares at th papers, not sure if she’s been had. The security guard is examining Lee’s bag. He sees her li notebook, pens. Some junk. He gestures that she can go. 131

dialogues.speaker: A132
dialogues.text: Lee exits, sighing with relief. Suddenly the security gua emerges and calls after Lee.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ma’am? Lee freezes, and turns back to him slowly. He approaches reaching his hand out. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) You forgot these. He hands her a pair of gloves. Lee nods appreciatively. 132

dialogues.speaker: A133
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 93A.

dialogues.speaker: A133
dialogues.text: Lee looks straight ahead, anxious to get home. 133 EXT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - AFTERNOON 133 Lee walks up to her building with her duffel and typewrit Andrei comes out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi, Andrei.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: Miss Israel. There were two men looking for you. They said they were FBI. What?!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: I told them you weren’t home. They were asking all kinds of questions. About what you do, what kind of things you write. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CYEFM
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) I’ve seen all those typewriters in your apartment LEE Did you say anything?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREI
dialogues.text: No, no. I said nothing. Are you in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That remains to be seen. 134 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - AFTERNOON 134 She enters and finds the place is an unrecognizable mess. Glasses, bottles, records out of their sleeves. Hello? No response.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She looks around, increasingly disturbed. LEE (CONT’D) Jack? Hello?! (beat) Jersey! Mama’s home. What did he do to our home, Jersey? Come on girl. She glances around and then looks under the couch. Lee remains there, frozen. After a beat, she lifts her he up and her face crumples. She covers her face in her hand Jack stumbles out of the bedroom, half asleep. Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He glances behind him nervously. JACK (CONT’D) (loudly whispering) Alright this looks bad, I know. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 95. 134

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (re: Kurt, whispering) I couldn’t resist him, he’s so adorable you have to under

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why? I’ll clean up! She throws his jacket and back pack at him. Lee is furiou

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: My cat is dead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh no. I’m so sorry. Out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just then Kurt appears from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Jack? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh for fuck’s sake. GET OUT OF MY HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Your house?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Darling, I can explainBut Kurt is done. Jack is caught be Kurt and Lee in the same moment. Lee goes to the front do and holds it open, unable to make eye contact with Jack. Kurt, grabbing his clothes and shoes, makes his way out, reluctantly follows him.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: This is too fucked up for me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Lee) Lee I’m so sorry. It probably just happened. It’s not my fault. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 96. 134 JACK (CONT’D) I gave her the pills. I did what you told me, Lee. (beat) Let me in! She pulls the dead cat from under the couch. Kneeling by couch, she cradles it in her lap as she cries.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) I’m sorry, Jersey. I shouldn’t have left you. 135 EXT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 135 Lee holds a shoe box and walks into the vet’s building. 136 INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY She walks up to Rachel at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi, Ms. Israel. Is Jersey okay? Lee can only manage to shake her head. RACHEL (CONT’D) Oh. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a backyard or anything. (beat) I didn’t know what to do with her. Rachel now sees the box.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, we can take care of that. Lee hands it to her. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry for your loss. Lee heads for the door. 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 97. INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 137 Lee is in the kitchen, drunk and pacing and dialing the phone. Hello? MARIE’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yes, I’d like to speak to Elaine. MARIE’S VOICE Is this Lee?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is she there please? MARIE’S VOICE Actually she’s LEE (cutting her off) I just had something of importance to tell her. At what time do you expect her return? MARIE’S VOICE I’m not actually sure. (beat) You’ve got to stop calling here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t have to do anything, Marie. I just need people to take my calls, instead of having some piece of shit tell me what I have to do. That’s what I think I deserve. She slams the phone down. 138 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - DAY 138 At a table, Lee hands Jack a bunch of letters in a folder She is short, averting her eyes. She is all business, col

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Let them authenticate all they want. They’re real. Don’t settle.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lee - are we going to talk about it? I am really sorry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 98. 138 She stays the course.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Did you make an appointment at Armada?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes. I rang him. He said to come at one.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: All right. Afterward, come right here.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll do good, you’ll see. I’ll make it up to you. Lee doesn’t reply to this. There is no making it up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get a written receipt. I want to know how much you’re paid.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Okay, if that’s what you want. He’ll give it to me. That little fucker eats up my shtick. (laughing a little) Ooh that sounded dirty. He laughs, trying to engage Lee like they used to. She wo JACK (CONT’D) Come on. How long are you going to freeze me out?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) I trusted you. I don’t know if you’ve noticed, but I don’t do that. You have reminded me why that is.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (sincerely pleading) Lee, I took care of the cat. I swear. It was an accident, and I feel awful.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And your little friend? Who was not supposed to be in my house. Does he feel awful too?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I haven’t seen him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 99. 138

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We will continue doing business together because I have no options, but we aren’t friends, I don’t think we actually ever were. Lee-

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We will meet in public. You will not fuck this up like you fuck everything else up in your life. Sell the letters. Get the money. And get a fucking receipt.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Fine. (after a moment, one more try) I onlyI’m done.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She looks him in the eye for the first time. He understan that it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ll be back after the sale. He gets up slowly and walks away. Lee sits stoically. 139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 Jack walks up the street, smoking, nervous, headed for Ar Booksellers. 140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 Paul, more uneasy than usual, is handling the letters tha Jack has offered him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Aren’t these fabulous? I just know someone is going to treasure them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They’re terrific. Where on earth did you find these? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 100. 140

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My granny just passed and I discovered them when I was cleaning out her junk. They’re worth something, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How much are you asking for them?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I guess around three hundred each? Paul goes to write a check. Jack is taken aback by how ea this is. JACK (CONT’D) Actually, do you have cash? Paul instantly counts out six hundred dollars cash and pu it in Jack’s hand. 141 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - DAY 141 Already hammered, Lee sits at the bar, scribbling in a notebook, doing calculations of the money she owes. She i agitated and more than a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) I need another. Craig comes over, starts to pour.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That’s debateable.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (too defensive) What did you say? Craig looks up, surprised by her anger.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Nothing, Lee. He walks away, shaking his head a little.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Fuckin’ judgemental jack-ass. 142

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 142 Jack is cornered by Solanas and Doyle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 101. 142

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (in a panic) I’m pretty sure they’re stolen, I didn’t want to ask. But she asked me to sell them as a favor so I said okay!

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: As a favor? You don’t accept a cut?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, a small one. Very small. But I don’t know where they came from, honest! I’ll tell you anything you want to know. Am I in big trouble? He gives his puppy dog eyes. 143 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - CONTINUOUS 143 Lee is drunk, looks up at a picture of Tallulah Bankhead the wall, amongst all the other famous people who used to frequent the bar. Then back to her drink. Empties it. She mumbling to herself. This is a Lee we haven’t seen before

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (mumbling, barely audible) ...probably ran off with the money. I’ll kill him....

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (from end of the bar) Did you say something? Lee shakes her head, shooing him off. She crumples the piece of paper she was scribbling on. Lo back to the picture, weirdly distracted by it. Glances at clock. It’s 2:30.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (mumbling, only making out every couple of words) No, at least until 3... (then, calling to Craig) Actually one more. Craig sets one down next to her. LEE (CONT’D) (pointing to the picture) I wrote a biography of her once, in another life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 102. 143

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yes, you’ve told me. More and more festive people are crowding into the bar. C attends to the other patrons. Someone tries to sit at the stool next to Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No! I’m waiting for someone. The guy rolls his eyes, walking off. Lee puts on her headphones, to drown out the crowd. LEE (CONT’D) (muttering to herself) Nobody has any patience anymore. People are crowding into Lee’s space though. Finally, Lee gets up to move down the bar, comes face to face with the agents, approaching her.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: Lee Israel? She takes off her headphones, confused. The patrons of th bar, as well as Craig all notice what’s going on. It take Lee a moment. AGENT SOLANAS (CONT’D) I’m agent Solanas and this is Agent Doyle. We’re here to deliver a subpoena to appear before a federal grand jury. He hands Lee an envelope. AGENT SOLANAS (CONT’D) Your appearance is scheduled for two weeks from today. You will find the address on the enclosed documents. You are forbidden to destroy any evidence pertinent to this case.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: We’ve intercepted your employee, Jack Hock. He is cooperating as are the dealers you did business with. (beat) Anything you’d like to say? Anything on your mind that you’d like to get off your chest? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 103. 143

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think it behooves me to be a wallflower at this particular dance. Until I can get a hold of an attorney.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SOLANAS
dialogues.text: As you wish. (beat) Mr. Hock requests that you not try to reach him or telephone or harass him in any way. And by law you are forbidden to contact him regardless. Lee is stung. 144 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 144 Frantic, Lee attacks her research with a scissors, throwi the pieces into different garbage bags. She rips papers a crumples up anything she can find. 145

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 Carrying several black plastic bags, Lee hustles down the street. She glances around her, paranoid, chucking bags into vari piles of street garbage waiting for pick up. One by one, Lee throws a typewriter into a different garb can. 146

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 146 Lee sits opposite an UPTIGHT FEMALE LAWYER. She’s picking hair off her old jacket, visibly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: UPTIGHT LAWYER
dialogues.text: (reading from a document) Investigating agents spoke with the Assistant Librarian for Manuscripts at Yale Library... He confirmed that the letters sold to CW-1 did belong to Yale and that forged copies of these letters were now in the files.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I could’ve told you that. But you have a very good reputation, surely you can - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 104. 146

dialogues.speaker: UPTIGHT LAWYER
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) Ms. Israel, I’m afraid that you will spend a fair amount of time behind bars, despite my reputation. (beat) You were deliberate, your crimes were premeditated and I have to say, numerous. It says here (reads) You created and sold approximately four hundred letters. That many?

dialogues.speaker: UPTIGHT LAWYER
dialogues.text: You’re proud.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Did you read them?

dialogues.speaker: UPTIGHT LAWYER
dialogues.text: No. Why would I read them? (considering) I believe the only way to handle this is to plead insanity and frankly, I don’t think we’d have any problem proving it. Lee stares at her, doesn’t like this one bit. 147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 Lee sits across from LLOYD, a handsome lawyer. She rubs h temples. Headache? Awful.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Can’t blame you. (reading papers) Looking at all this... it’s pretty bad. Now that said, can I say - those letters were pretty damned impressive. I especially enjoyed the Louise Brooks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 105. 147

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (beat) I’m afraid they were my finest moment.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m sure that’s not true. (beat) You fell on hard times. You had a sick cat. You couldn’t get a writing job and you didn’t mean for it to get out of hand, but then some jerk blackmails you and you panic. You never meant for it to continue, or to steal, but you had to pay him back or you’d go to jail. (beat) Depending on the judge, I think at worst you could conceivably get a year and change. Lee looks panicked. LLOYD (CONT’D) You’ll bring a book. (beat) Look, if you want me to represent you, you’re going to have to do a few things before appearing in court. Like what?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Clean up your act. First, you’re getting a job. Any kind of job. And second, you’re enrolling in community service to show how penitent you are.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What - what kind of service?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Something with children? Jesus no.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Animals, sick people. Whatever. You’re going to show that you have turned over a new leaf. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’ve got to go to AA. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 106. 147

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s absurd. He stares at her. It doesn’t seem possible that her spiri could sink even lower. LEE (CONT’D) I want to ask you something. (beat) So, everyone I sold to - do you think they all know?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. They probably all know. But right now, that’s the least of your worries. 148 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - DAY 148 In the mostly empty bar, dressed for court, Lee sits and drinks, somewhat a pariah. A few regulars whisper about h

dialogues.speaker: A149
dialogues.text: Lee walks up the steps of the intimidating courthouse. 149

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 Lee and Lloyd sit on a bench outside the courtroom. Lee i sweating in her heavy jacket as she anxiously rubs her ha against her thighs.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: We’re very lucky this is our judge. Very lucky. She doesn’t waste time with things like this. I have a good feeling. Try to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (handing her a mint, annoyed) You smell like alcohol. She shrugs and takes the mint. 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 150 In a simple, nearly empty courtroom, Lee and Lloyd stand before the JUDGE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 107. 150

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (continuing) She is seeking employment with Scholastic books as a copy editor, and has already put in over forty hours of community service at a cat shelter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Lee) Before I render my verdict, have you in the last twenty-four hours used drugs, pills, alcohol, anything that could affect your ability to understand what is going on? No ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Have you anything additional you would like to say to the court before I offer your sentence? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lloyd watches her carefully as she stands, and takes a de breath. What comes next begins as something rehearsed, bu devolves into a stream-of-consciousness confession. LEE (CONT’D) I have been living in a state of enormous guilt and anxiety for the past year. Not because I felt like I was doing something wrong, but because I was always afraid of being found out. I can’t specifically say that I regret my actionsLloyd clears his throat, urging L Lee-

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t. I thoroughly enjoyed writing these letters, living in the world of Dorothy Parker and Noel Coward, pretending I was something I am not. In many ways, this has been the best time of my life. It’s the only time recently I can remember being proud of the work I was doing. (then) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 108. 150

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it wasn’t my work, was it? I was hiding behind these people, their names. Because if I’d actually put myself out there, done my own work, then I would be opening myself up to criticism. And I’m too much of a coward for all of that. I’ve lost my cat- the only soul that truly loved me, maybe ever- and I lost my friend - who might have been an idiot, but tolerated me, and was nice to have around. And I’ve realized that I’m not a real writer. In the end, it was not worth it. This hits Lee in a surprising way. Lloyd looks at her nervously. She returns to her script. LEE (CONT’D) I will accept the judgement of the court as valid and fulfill whatever sentence I may receive with the full understanding that I have earned said punishment. A moment. The judge nods.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Lee Israel, the court sentences you to five years probation plus six months house arrest. You may only leave home to go to and from your place of employment, your work in the community, and to alcoholic’s anonymous meetings.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (blurting) I don’t have anywhere to go.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You are not to leave the state or consort with felons and you are to pay restitution to your victims within your means. Lloyd grins at Lee, nodding. Lee stares, in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (quietly to Lee) This is a good thing. Very fair. But Lee is reeling. The weight of everything is finally settled on her, and it is heavy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 109. 150

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (at her lowest) Mm hmm. Good. Lloyd doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: A151
dialogues.text: Lee walks out of the courthouse emptied and exhausted. 151 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 151 Lee enters her apartment. It is eerily empty. No typewrit No Jersey. No Jack. Jersey’s empty food bowl sits on the floor, taunting Lee. She checks her answering machine but no messages. She collapses onto the couch. She does not k where she will go from here. 152

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152 Lee sits on a bench waiting. After a moment she sees ELAI 45, coming toward her.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: It sounded important.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It was. It is. My phone got shut off. In case you tried to call. I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: They sit down and Elaine notices the cat hair on Lee’s jacket, picks at it. ELAINE (CONT’D) I see you brought Jersey with you. How is that old bitch?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s what I wanted to tell you, Elaine. She just died. Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I figured, since she was a gift from you- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 110. 152 Lee starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Was she? (beat) I’m so sorry, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I got too attached to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You going to get another?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No. I can’t replace her. It wouldn’t be right.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Maybe in time.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I do go to Aunt Eleanor’s pretty regularly.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Oh god, I haven’t thought about that place in years! It’s still there? On 96th?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Exactly the same. Different cats.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (beat) You still on 82nd?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Where else would I be?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You look all right. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You can’t imagine what I’ve had to do to survive.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: We all have to do things we don’t want to do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 111. 152

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Maybe. I can’t remember the last time I was doing something because I wanted to do it. Elaine examines Lee, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping, Lee? This bit of kindness hits Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Fits and starts. But when you can’t recognize your own life it’s hard to find rest.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You’re having one of those times. You just gotta ride it out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I was supposed to be something so different than this. Wasn’t I? When we were together, people liked my work right?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: That’s why you wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No. I mean... I’ve wanted to see you for a long time. I’ve needed to see you, Elaine. I just... I’m in a crisis. And you know me.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: It always seemed more important to you that people liked your work than that they liked you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, of course.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: No, Lee. That’s not healthy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I guess not. ButELAINE You were so miserable. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 112. 152

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Yes you were. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I was happy with you.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Well, I appreciate that. We were happy there. For parts of it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It was more than parts of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: No, Lee. There was always a wall between us. Something I couldn’t penetrate.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I tried. God damnit. I tried more with you than with anyone ever.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: No you didn’t. You did everything you could to keep your distance. You lied, you drank constantly, you were selfinvolvedLEE Well, I didn’t say I was perfect.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: And the moment anyone wronged you, you cut them out. It was like you were looking for everyone to fail you, so you wouldn’t have stay connected.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well fuck. I always thought of myself as pleasantly prickly.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: More like a fortress of disdain. I could never get you to let down the wall- to trust me- and at some point I just stopped trying.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn’t. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 113. 152

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you were so afraid for anyone to get to know you - maybe you thought nobody would like what they saw. Such a shame. This takes Lee by surprise. Elaine starts to stand up, Le grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Wait - don’t go.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: This isn’t my job anymore, Lee. To talk you off the ledge. It’s exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Who is she? Elaine sighs, she was trying to avoid this. Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m just curious.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: She’s a public advocate. She’s warm and it’s simple.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is she always a cunt to your old friends? I wouldn’t let her answer the phone if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: And there it is. I don’t know why I try. (she makes a motion of a wall going up) You’re never going to change. Everyone is always wronging you - nobody appreciates you, nobody gives you what you deserve.... (short beat) And nothing is ever your fault. Lee is stunned. ELAINE (CONT’D) I’ve got a class. (then) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 114. 152 ELAINE (CONT’D) It was good to see you, for a minute there. She turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (beat) Say hi to Marie! Elaine doesn’t turn around and Lee sits there, hating herself. Shit. LEE (CONT’D) 153

dialogues.speaker: A154
dialogues.text: INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT 153

dialogues.speaker: A154
dialogues.text: Lee lies in bed, staring up at the fan. She isn’t filled anxiety anymore. She is numb. She is lifeless, replaying Elaine’s words in her head. She pulls out Anna’s short st and begins to read. 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154 Lee walks past Anna’s bookshop. She sees Anna inside, tal to a customer. She knows she can’t go in. She stops and watches though. Suddenly Anna looks up and the two women eye contact. Anna breaks it and when she looks back up, Lee is gone. Sadly, Lee walks away. 155

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 155 156 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 156 Lee stares for a while. Finds nothing. She goes and sits at her one remaining, original type-wri She puts in a piece of paper. She thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 157 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 115. INT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON - SOME MONTHS LATER 157 Lee sits at a table - she doesn’t look good but she doesn look bad either. Craig brings her a scotch.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Haven’t seen your face in here in a while.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah well, I’m only allowed to leave the house for my AA meetings. Craig walks away shaking his head. Suddenly the door open and Jack comes in. He sees Lee, approaches her table. Is a coincidence? Jack looks a little thin, and walks with a crutch, babying one foot. LEE (CONT’D) Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugging) It was quite inconvenient. I had to move around some meetings, but I had my assistant cancel my afternoon. Lee smirks. It’s kind of Jack to make this easier.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Can I get you a drink? I’m buying. I’ve started counterfeiting money now. She smirks, this tickles Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not today. (off Lee’s surprise) It’s my new meds. Throwing my whole system off. Gin tastes like mouthwash. Takes the fun out of it. Lee is concerned, but doesn’t press.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I guess you were able to cut a deal? Ratting on me worked out?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Three years probation.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: At least you’re out and about. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 116. 157

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So are you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, I’m at an AA meeting on 10th street. Jack laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Criminals at large! (then) I couldn’t imagine what was so important that Lee Israel swallowed her pride and asked me to meet her. So spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m reconsidering.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh just tell me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well... I’ve been thinking about writing a new book. About what happened. About what I did. And about you, if you’ll let me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Like hell I will! What would my boyfriend think if he knew about my shadier dealings?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Do our crimes even count in your top ten of shady dealings? I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Fair enough. But I don’t want a book out there about me. I’m a very private person. Lee is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I have to do something. I have to write again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What about Fanny Price? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 117. 157

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Brice? No. I think for once I would like to write about one Lee Isreal. As terrifying as that sounds.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m still mad at you, you know. You treated me like shit. I don’t think you’re a very nice person.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I would agree with you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But I suppose you may be mad at me as well.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: If you didn’t look quite so decrepit, I would be.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes, well. I guess it’s not some huge plot twist. It was going to catch up to me eventually.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You have fucked your way through Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I would like that on my tombstone. They share a morbid laugh. JACK (CONT’D) With the addition of: but he steered clear of the boroughs. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Will you make me 29? And with perfect skin? And don’t make me sound stupid? Lee is quiet, realizing he is agreeing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 118. 157 JACK (CONT’D) Oh fuck it. Write whatever you want. It’s not like anyone reads your books anyways.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve already written five chapters. Jack laughs. LEE (CONT’D) (quietly) Thank you. Lee reaches out and touches Jack’s hand. This lingers for just a moment and then Jack stands, breaking it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m late for a board meeting. My driver is waiting. The life of a millionaire. They both smile, going with the bit. Jack starts toward t door. Crossing in front of Lee. Lee stifles a little laug Jack looks back... What? JACK (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No... I was so tempted to trip you, just now. Jack laughs, against his better judgement.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Wow, you’re ... a horrid cunt, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So are you, Jack. Good luck. You too.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He leaves. 158 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 158 Sitting at her dining table, Lee writes on an old, large computer. She sips scotch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 119. 158 A kitten scampers around her ankle and settles on the keyboard. The place is cleaned up again, but still Lee’s. 159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159 Springtime. Lee sits on a bench, content. She eats a hot and watches people pass. 160

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160 Lee walks down the street and backtracks, having seen something in a bookstore window that has caught her eye. a mounted letter from Dorothy Parker. One that Lee has written. 161

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 161 Lee addresses the bookseller.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: My friend’s birthday is coming up and he’d love to own that Dorothy Parker in the window.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSELLER
dialogues.text: She’s a beauty, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Can I ask how much a letter like that runs?

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSELLER
dialogues.text: We’re asking nineteen hundred, framed and matted, and she comes complete with a letter of authenticity. Lee’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Does the letter of authenticity come with a letter of authenticity?

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, I can assure you. It’s the real thing. No one can write like Ms. Parker could. Not before and not since. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 120. 161 The bittersweet compliment is music to her ears.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, that might be out of my price range, but thank you very much. 162 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 162 Lee sits at her old typewriter (the one she already owned and writes. LEE’S VOICE My dear sir, I offer my droopy salutations from the Great Beyond. I understand that you’re selling my personal letters to the tune of nearly two grand. To think poor Lee Israel received a tiny fraction of that sum when she sold them to someone, who then sold them to you. 163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 We see the man through the front window, reading this let He looks into the distance, considering. Disturbed, he mo to the shop window. LEE’S VOICE I dearly hope this letter will not affect the selling price of your valuable artifact. As I most famously muttered mere moments after my cremation: “Darling, excuse my dust.” Yours, Dorothy Parker. The bookseller removes the letter from the window display And then decides to put it back. © 2017 WILLOW AND OAK, INC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. NO PORT
